data.text: Looking for Vacuum Insulated Stainless Steel Water Bottles

I'm looking for recommendations for tried and tested stainless steel water bottles (preferably vacuum insulated) that can take the heat and stay cold all day. I've tried all the plastic ones and none of them really last the full day. Thanks!
KleanKanteens
data.author: Dave Becker-Ellison

data.text: You‚Äôre obviously looking for an insulated stainless steel bottle and I recommend Yeti. I‚Äôve tried several other popular brands and I feel that hands down Yeti is the best. They‚Äôre backed by an amazing warranty, have various sizes, they‚Äôre by far the most durable and they use the best stainless steel. Many of the other brands look the same, but they‚Äôre inferior to Yeti. The others are more prone to denting or replacement parts aren‚Äôt easily obtained and even the other big brands like Hydro Flask use a lower quality stainless steel that actually develops rust spots. The Yeti stuff is even dishwasher safe so you can get it good and cleaned and sanitized. Yeti is the only brand that I buy. You just can‚Äôt beat it. https://www.yeti.com/drinkware/bottles

data.text: generally agree, although I‚Äôve never had issues with hydro flask rusting. I would imagine there could be subpar batches that might, though. I‚Äôve been surprised by how durable the powder coat finish has been on several.
data.author: Steve Barberie

data.text: I used to like Hydro Flask stuff. I have 4 of their bottles and 2 of their pint cups, but in my experience it just doesn‚Äôt hold up and it dent‚Äôs quite easily in my experience and then the paint flecks and fades. So I discovered Yeti about 5 years ago and never looked back.

data.text: the yeti is worth it. I work in construction and that‚Äôs how I keep my water cold. I‚Äôve had ice left after 2 days.

data.text: I don‚Äôt support companies like RTIC that have been found guilty of trademark infringement and copying trade dress, just flat out blatant rip-offs of others work and products. RTIC even went so far as to alter photographs of YETI coolers, add their logo and pass them off as their own for marketing.
data.author: Eric Yantis

data.text: I guess we all have to choose our battles. And imo there are much bigger fish to fry in the world of big business. But you do you. ‚úåÔ∏è
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: I tried Yeti, Hydro Flask, Contigo, Kleen Kanteen and others. They are ALL dependable for the first few months. They ALL keep your cold drinks cold and your hot drinks hot for at least 8 hours. They ALL dent from a hard knock. The paint on ALL of them scratches off. Yeti feels like it's built better, but I don't think it's worth the price for its functionality (my priorities). You can buy a new Contigo twice a year for the cost of keeping a Yeti for 2 years. Judge for yourself if you want to spend extra. Hydro Flask wide mouth bottles are easier to find replacement parts, but they are made in China, so you may find a bottle from a bad batch.
data.author: Hagay Vider

data.text: All of the stainless steel drink ware is made in China.
data.author: Eric Yantis

data.text: Stainless steel absorbs and holds heat very well. Definately won't keep your liquids cold. Aluminium üëç

data.text: Thanks Mark! I should have been more specific, I'm looking for something vacuum insulated and quite strong, I mainly do gravel here in Spain and have been known to take a tumble on more than one occasion.
data.author: Scott Lazar

data.text: What are you talking about? A vacuum insulated bottle will keep its liquid contents cold all day in the hottest summer heat.
data.author: Eric Yantis

data.text: Like I said, Yeti. If you can get Yeti in Spain you will not be disappointed. I keep a Yeti stainless steel vacuum insulated bottle in my car for after ride hydration and even on the hottest summer days, I live in California, but I‚Äôve been to Spain in the Summer and I know it can get incredibly hot there too, but even after having the the bottle in my car all day and the container is too hot on the outside to touch without a towel or gloves, the water inside is still ice cold. Vacuum sealed aluminum bottles like the other guy mentioned aren‚Äôt even really a thing, so good luck finding one of any quality.
data.author: Eric Yantis

data.text: yees the vacuum flaskü§ônot the bottle. Big deal is drinking enough! Easy 5l.per day
data.author: Mark Jackson

data.text: Aluminum has a thermal conductivity in W/mK at 20¬∞C and 1 bar of 239. Stainless steel is 25. Aluminum is almost ten times more thermally conductive than stainless steel. Furthermore as Eric points out, a vacuum insulation layer reduces the 25 to below 1 though it could get as low as 0.01, with better caps or an aerogel layer. So a vacuum insulated layer flask is hundreds of times better at insulating than an aluminum container. The thermal (specific heat) capacity (in J/g ¬∞C) of aluminum is 0.89, while for stainless steel it is 0.5. Aluminum has a density of 2.7 g/m¬≥ while stainless steel is 7.9 g/m¬≥. This means aluminum holds twice as much heat as stainless steel by weight, but by volume the stainless steel holds 39% more heat. Generally stainless steel can hold with less volume, with 505MPa vs 276 MPa for aluminum. Thus for the same tensile strength of material, aluminum will still hold more heat. Thus per their physical facts, none of what you wrote is true. Aluminum both holds and absorbs heat more than an equally strong vessel in stainless steel, even if not vacuum insulated. Adding vacuum insulation helps drastically more.

data.text: If you want to try a plastic bottle, I have had good luck with the polar bottles. They are insulated and have a nice cap to keep the mouth piece clean.

data.text: My Yeti is Great Divide tested. Worked great, still had ice after a day of riding in the heat. But I shipped it home, finding it necessary to cut way back on what I tried to carry over The Rockies.
data.author: Andy Simmons

data.text: I haven't backpacked with it but I use hydroflask at home. I've put ice in it and left it in the car for hours and still had ice. Even in 90 degree temps.
data.author: Melissa Kandiko

data.text: I use Contigo 3 -24 ounce stainless bottles for the cages, much cheaper and just as good as yeti, I also have several 40 oz hydro flask knockoffs, they look like they would fit great on the front forks, they keep coffee hot for 8 hrs easy and iced tea cold til the next day, used them outdoors on a construction site for years, I have some expensive pelican roto mold coolers, but I find I get by real well with the cheaper water bottles, we also have and rtic and yeti coozies, I cannot tell the difference, but if I lost the yeti, I'd be pissed not so much the rtic at a third of the price, yeti, hydro flask, overpriced imho

data.text: I‚Äôd test before believing insulation claims. Zojirushi abandoned its quality and its exacting performance claim when it moved insulated stainless bottle production offshore 30 years ago. Due to weight penalty of stainless insulation, I‚Äôd say real hot or real cold after a day of hard riding would be nice but no more essential than sex. Carry 250-500g more for a single cold instead of cool drink? Gonna call Door Dash to meet up for a refill? But, then, I think romance of hot meals is over-rated, for a day or a week, what with weight of stove and fuel.
